Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Development of an long wavelength nonlinear optical microscope for harmonic and autofluorescence imaging of biological tissues

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0959525
Campagnola

"This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5)."

Problems of overlapping spectra, photobleaching, low signal to noise and light scatter pose serious limitations on what can be achieved in practice in imaging tissues by fluorescence. Over the last 10-15 years nonlinear optical microscopy techniques have been developed and adopted widely, largely due to their ability to overcome many of these limitations. Most current nonlinear optical microscopes use excitation wavelengths between 700-1000 nm, as this is the standard tuning range of the widely used Ti:Sapphire femtosecond lasers. While these near infrared (NIR) wavelengths provide significantly deeper penetration (few hundred microns vs. 10 s of microns) into tissue than achievable with confocal laser scanning microscopes using visible excitation sources (e.g. 488, 514 nm), it would be of great biological and biomedical benefit to further improve upon this limit to achieve about 1 mm for imaging the collagen structure associated with tumors and other pathologies. To address this need, this proposal will engage researchers from biomedical engineering, physics, plant biology, cancer biology, and biophotonics to build a nonlinear microscopy platform capable of exciting intrinsic and extrinsic fluorophores from 680nm to 1300 nm. The instrument will be constructed from a Ti:Sapphire oscillator/ optical parametric oscillator (OPO) and a homebuilt laser scanning microscope optimized for longer wavelength excitation. When complete, the instrument will afford detection of 2 and 3-photon excited fluorescence, Second Harmonic Generation and Third Harmonic Generation. We anticipate that using the 1000-1300 nm tuning range provided by the optical parametric oscillator will provide an additional 2-3 fold increase in imaging depth in tissues. The successful construction and implementation of the instrumentation will enable a wide range of dynamic cell studies ranging from plant and cell models to animal models of breast cancer and ovarian cancer. These studies will thoroughly examine the potential of long wavelengths for deeper imaging and improved excitation of fluorophores that naturally excite further into the NIR. This construction will lay down the experimental framework for future biological studies that may benefit from longer wavelength based nonlinear optical approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we developed instrumentation designed to improve the imaging of tissues on an optical microscope platform. These efforts had both basic science components as well as translational aspects relevant to human health. In the latter category, the investigators study ovarian and breast cancer and are seeking to provide improved diagnostics for early disease detection. In this goal, our primary tool is Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) imaging microscopy. This modality is highly sensitive to changes in collagen content and organization, where this is relevant to cancer these characteristics can be highly different in normal and malignant tissues. For example, increased collagen density in the breast contributing to increased density seen in mammography has been associated with invasive disease. Mammography does not have sufficient resolution or specificity to detect these changes in early stage disease. For ovarian cancer the situation is yet more serious as there are no reliable diagnostics of early state disease. Microscope based platforms based on SHG that are both highly sensitive and specific could improve this situation.

 

To better enable the transfer of the SHG microscope technology to clinical applications we need a deeper understanding of the underlying physics, as this is a relatively new approach.  Thus, part of this project was dedicated to developing more sophisticated modeling tools to interpret and analyze the data and we now have a better framework with which to work. These software tools will be made freely available to the scientific community. We concurrently developed superior instrumentation to acquire both higher quality images than previously possible as well as provide new capabilities. We have developed two new methods based on light scattering to further compare the physical structure of normal and malignant tissues, and the analysis software is freely available. The light scattering tools have now been combined with the SHG imaging modality on an integrated platform that could be used diagnostically. For example, we are using this approach to compare structural changes across a range of disease stage in ovarian cancer. An example comparing the collagen in normal ovary and a low-grade malignancy is show in the figure.

 

The project also had educational and outreach activities. Two graduate students were trained during the project. These students and others in the investigators’ labs are actively involved in student chapters of professional societies. In addition to career development, these chapters participate in K-12 outreach activities throughout the year. The Principle Investigator is on the advisory boards for the local Project Lead the Way program in his community.
